title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Preface and Definitions
This guide is intended to be a place to host our accumulated institutional knowledge and standard operating procedures regarding the TailWinds project. Weâ€™ve already had mild amounts of staff turnover, so the hope is that this will alleviate some of the pain associated with onboarding â€“ or â€œre-onboardingâ€ our current members after periods away from the project.
Inspired by Gavin Fayâ€™s Lab Manual, this is a living document which everyone should be able to edit.

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Acronyms

BACI

Before-After-Control-Impact design

BAG

Before-After-Gradient design

BSB

black sea bass, Centropristis striata

CBL

Chesapeake Biological Laboratory

EFP

Exempted Fishing Permit

FRM

Fishery Resource Monitoring. One of the three core TailWinds projects. Include FRS #?

IACUC

Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee

LOA

Letter of Authorization/Acknowledgement

MCBP

Maryland Coastal Bays Program

MD DNR

Maryland Department of Natural Resources

MDWEA

Maryland Wind Energy Area, also known as the Maryland Lease Area

MMM

Marine Mammal Monitoring. One of the three core TailWinds projects. Include FRS #?

PAM

Passive acoustic monitoring

RTWB

(Near) Real-Time Whale Buoy. One of the three core TailWinds projects. FRS #?

UMCES

University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science

WHOI

Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Definitions

Console

Where you type commands into R.

Terminal

Command-line interface to the computer. Access in RStudio via Tools > Terminal > New Terminal

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Software

LFDCS

. Allows the detection, characterization, classification, and reporting of marine mammal tonal vocalizations

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Hardware

C-POD

Recording device that consists of a hydrophone and a processor which detects â€œtrainsâ€ of echolocation clicks from dolphins and porpoises. Operates in the 20-160 kHz range. Manufactured by Chelonia, Ltd.. Successor to the T-POD, predecessor to the F-POD.

Delphinus

Server located on the UMCES-CBL campus

DMON

Digital acoustic monitoring instrument. Deployed on the RTWB, it is capable of recording and processing audio in near real-time using custom detection algorithms

F-POD

Recording device that consists of a hydrophone and a processor which detects â€œtrainsâ€ of echolocation clicks from dolphins and porpoises. Operates in the 20-160 kHz range. Manufactured by Chelonia, Ltd.. Successor to the C-POD.

LS1X

Hydrophone manufactured by Loggerhead, Inc.

Rockhopper

Whale acoustic recording device, owned/operated by Cornell. Successor to the MARU devices.

VR2AR

Fish telemetry receiver with built-in acoustic release device. Operates in the 69 kHz range. Manufactured by Innovasea (formerly named Vemco).

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Source vs Visual editor
Pretty much everything you write for the Guide (and the website) will use Markdown. Some basics are outlined on the Quarto website. Note that if youâ€™re Googling for something related to Markdown formatting, anything sold as â€œRMarkdownâ€ will also work.
All of the different options can be confusing and create a barrier to entry. Enter: the RStudio Visual Markdown editor.
RStudio has a visual editor for markdown documents (also called a â€œwhat-you-see-is-what-you-getâ€ editor, or WYSIWYG, or â€œwizzy-wigâ€, how fun!). You can activate this by clicking â€œVisualâ€ in the top left of your code editing pane. Now, R will act as if it were MS Word, allowing you to skip the code and add things with a few clicks. If youâ€™re curious as to what the markdown code looks like, click â€œSourceâ€ and it will switch to editing as if you were a coding expert.

title: 1Â  Quarto
text:
General notes:

index.qmd has to be the first page and it canâ€™t be numbered. Messes up the file organization, but oh well.

title: Website and Guide
section: Other websites of which we are covetous
text:
Other websites of which we are covetous

https://rowlrs.marine.rutgers.edu/

title: 4Â  R
text:
4.1 Install R
So, if you donâ€™t have R installed on your machine, go ahead and download it here, then install. Weâ€™ve already run into issues where old versions of the programs weâ€™re using can mess up how the website renders, so check to see if thereâ€™s a new version of R if you havenâ€™t updated in a while. The most-recent version of R, version 4.2.2, was issued on Oct 31, 2022. Am I up to date?

R.Version()$version.string

[1] "R version 4.2.2 (2022-10-31 ucrt)"


Yep.

title: 4Â  R
text:
4.2 RStudio
Again, this isnâ€™t the only program that will run Quarto, Iâ€™m just assuming that itâ€™s common language at this point. If you get in trouble and need to Google something, chances are that people will already assume youâ€™re using RStudio. Download by following this link and install.
If you already have RStudio installed, go ahead and check that itâ€™s the most-recent version (version 2022.12.0.353). Am I up to date?

rstudioapi::versionInfo()$version

Yes.

title: 4Â  R
text:
4.3 Quarto
Iâ€™m fairly certain that RStudio comes with a version of Quarto, the program weâ€™ll use to build the website, installed. However, we need to make sure it is the most up-to-date version. So, go ahead and follow that link and download/install Quarto anyway.
Once you install it, restart R/RStudio. Then go to Tools > Terminal >New Terminal and type
quarto --version
It should return 1.2.313 or greater. If it doesnâ€™t, let me know!

4.3.1 Quarto extensions
Okay, I got a little cute and put fun little icons linking to everyoneâ€™s various social media presence on the Team page. Iâ€™ve found out that now, because Iâ€™ve done that, everyone needs to have the cutesy little icon packages downloaded onto their computer. Donâ€™t worry, theyâ€™re safe (and kind of neat if you want to give them a look).

4.3.1.1 Font Awesome
Font Awesome icons are just what they say they are: some awesome icons! There are literally thousands of them â€“ go check them out. They even have a wind turbine, but you have to pay for it. ğŸ™
Anyway, we need to install an extension to get them to work with Quarto. Go to Tools > Terminal > New Terminal and type:
quarto install extension quarto-ext/fontawesome
Thatâ€™s it!


4.3.1.2 academicons
Academicons are the academicâ€™s answer to Font Awesome icons. They have icons for Google Scholar, Orcid, Data Dryad, Clarivate (nÃ©e Web of Science), the list goes on. To install the extension, go to Tools > Terminal > New Terminal and type:
quarto install extension schochastics/academicons

title: 4Â  R
text:
4.4 GitHub
Pop on over to GitHub and sign up for a free account. After youâ€™re done, let me know and Iâ€™ll add you to the TailWinds GitHub organization.

title: 5Â  Installing Git
text:
5.1 Tell Git who you are
We need to tell Git who we are, so that all of our changes can be tied to our name and, later, our GitHub account.
I want to be called â€œMike Oâ€™Brienâ€, and my GitHub account is tied to my work email, obrien@umces.edu. I would enter:

install.packages('usethis')
usethis::use_git_config(user.name = "Mike O'Brien",
                        user.email = "obrien@umces.edu")

Adjust the above code to your own name/email associated with your GitHub account.

title: 5Â  Installing Git
text:
5.2 Connecting your computer to GitHub
Pay attention to the section on setting up a personal access token (PAT). This wonâ€™t matter at all while your working on the website, but will come back to bite you once you try to send your changes to GitHub. The easiest way is just to follow the instructions on Happy Git and accept the defaults. There are more specifics at that link, but the steps more or less look like this:

Download the usethis package and run the create_github_token function


install.packages('usethis')
usethis::create_github_token()


This will open a website. Click â€œGenerate tokenâ€.
KEEP THIS WINDOW OPEN. It will give you a gibberish string that is basically your computer-to-computer password. Again, for now, KEEP THIS WINDOW OPEN.
Type the following into R:


gitcreds::gitcreds_set()


Copy the PAT from the window you kept open and paste it into R. If everything worked as itâ€™s supposed to, you should be able to send your changes to GitHub when the time comes.

title: 6Â  Clone
text:
6.1 Aside: Forking
Cloning someone elseâ€™s GitHub repository is called â€œforkingâ€. This makes a complete copy of the repository and places it into your GitHub account. You can then use the rest of the steps in this guide to make adjustments to their code.
Generally, when you wish to contribute to someone elseâ€™s package/code/repository, you:

Fork it to your GitHub account,
Clone the forked repository to your computer,
Create a new branch (see the next step in this guide),
Commit your changes to the new branch,
Push them back to GitHub,
Open a pull request for the original repositoryâ€™s maintainer to pull your changes into their version of the repository.

title: 7Â  Branch
text:
7.1 Making a branch
Note that these instructions are intentionally redundant to the section on making a branch to edit the Guide. You can make a new branch either by:

On GitHub, clicking the box on the top left that says â€œmasterâ€ and typing in whatever you want to call the new branch,
Clicking â€œNew Branchâ€ in the Git pane in RStudio

If you used method #1, pull the GitHub repository. The new branch will appear on the right side of the Git pane. If you used method #2, the branch should automatically be pushed to GitHub and RStudio will switch to this branch.

title: 8Â  Write
text:
Now weâ€™re going to create or edit Quarto (.qmd) files for the desired page.
The Quarto website has really thorough guides on how to do this. Slava and I are also on call via Slack!
Generally:

Click the â€œPullâ€ button in the Git tab. This will download any changes that have made to the website that you donâ€™t have.
Go to File > New File > Quarto Document to make a new page.
Write whatever you want to go on the page.
If you want the file to show up on the websiteâ€™s navigation bar, edit the _quarto.yml file â€“ this serves as the websiteâ€™s map. Feel free to skip this step if you donâ€™t want people to navigate to the page just yet. This is similar to the current page youâ€™re on â€“ you can access directly through the URL, but not by clicking to it.
If you want to take a quick glimpse at what the page you are editing will look like, click the â€œRenderâ€ button at the top of the editing pane, between the magnifying glass and cog. This will not change any other page or the locations to which the navigation bar points you.
If you made changes to the navigation bar or are ready to nudge things to the actual website, go to Build > Preview Site. This will convert everything to HTML behind the scenes.

title: 9Â  Commit
text:
Saving a version of all of the files in your repository is called a â€œcommitâ€. To do so, click the â€œCommitâ€ button in the Git pane. It will open another window showing you all of the files that have changed and their difference from previous versions: green means that something has been added and red means that something has been removed.
Click the little box in the â€œStagedâ€ column next to a file or files, then type a little note as to what youâ€™ve changed in the â€œCommit messageâ€ box. Then click the â€œCommitâ€ button et voilÃ ! These frozen snapshots of differences in your code or text will be stored on your computer and can be accessed later if necessary.
From Happy Git:

The daily workflow is probably not dramatically different from what you do currently. You work in the usual way, writing R scripts or authoring reports in LaTeX or R Markdown. But instead of only saving individual files, periodically you make a commit, which takes a snapshot of all the files in the entire project. If you have ever versioned a file by adding your initials or the date, you have effectively made a commit, albeit only for a single file. It is a version that is significant to you and that you might want to inspect or revert to later. Periodically, you push commits to GitHub. This is like sharing a document with colleagues on DropBox or sending it out as an email attachment. By pushing to GitHub, you make your work and all your accumulated progress accessible to others.

Donâ€™t be afraid to â€œcommitâ€ changes early and often â€“ think of these as breadcrumbs leading you back from where you came. If youâ€™re confident you can get back there, no need to commit everything. If youâ€™re trailblazing through uncharted territory, you probably want to commit more often.

title: 10Â  Pull
text:
No, weâ€™re not shooting skeet.
There will probably come a time when someone has made changes to the website between the time that you last downloaded things from GitHub and now. If you try to send your changes (commits) back up to GitHub, it will stop and let you know that things have changed.
In order to get ahead of this, click the â€œPullâ€ button. This will pull the changes from GitHub onto your computer. Hopefully, itâ€™ll go ahead and merge everything together for you. If it canâ€™t â€“ usually when you have edited the same lines that someone else has â€“ it will combine the two versions of the files and ask you to sort it out. This usually means opening the files and making an executive decision about what text/code you wish to keep.

title: 11Â  Push
text:
Take a deep breath, like Lamaze for your code.
Now that everything is in line, compile the website one more time via Build > Render, commit changes, and click the â€œPushâ€ button. This pushes all of the changes youâ€™ve logged on your computer (via commits) to GitHub. If youâ€™ve been editing the master branch, this will automatically change the website.
If youâ€™ve been editing in your own branch, things are less stressful. A new branch is your own little sandbox â€“ nothing will get added to the website before itâ€™s approved by Mike. To get that done, you need to open a pull request (next section).
If you get an error that looks like thisâ€¦
remote: Support for password authentication was removed on August 13, 2021. Please use a personal access token instead.
remote: Please see https://github.blog/2020-12-15-token-authentication-requirements-for-git-operations/ for more information.
fatal: Authentication failed for 'https://github.com/OWNER/REPO.git/'
â€¦you need to let GitHub know that youâ€™re allowed to make changes to your account. Refer back to the section on installing Git.

title: 12Â  Pull request
text:
12.1 Open a pull request
To open a pull request:\

Go to the websiteâ€™s GitHub page
Select your branch by clicking the button that says â€œmainâ€ on the left just above all of the code.
There will be a button that says â€œCompare & pull requestâ€. Click it.
This opens a â€œOpen a pull requestâ€ page. Go ahead and make a note about what this is going to do and click â€œCreate pull requestâ€.
At this point, you and Mike will start to have a conversation about anything that needs to be adjusted before going live on the website. Hopefully the conversation will be short, and the request can be directly merged!
After thr pull request is accepted, GitHub will offer to delete the branch. As we want branches to target singular issues/tasks, itâ€™s good to go ahead and let this happen. Donâ€™t worry, all of the changes youâ€™ve made are cataloged in commits, which have now been tacked onto the main branch!

title: 12Â  Pull request
text:
12.2 Prune a deleted branch
So youâ€™ve created a branch, made some edits, and had your pull request accepted. Now, you have a branch that was likely deleted on GitHub but is still hanging around on your computer. We can â€œpruneâ€ this branch by running the following in the Terminal, assuming that â€œbranch-to-deleteâ€ is the name of the branch you want to delete:
git branch -d branch-to-delete
git fetch -p

title: 13Â  Guide editing
text:
13.1 Guide editing workflow

Clone the TailWinds Guide repository: https://github.com/Tail-Winds/TailWinds-Guide
If youâ€™re making relatively minor changes, commit them to the master branch.
If youâ€™re making substantial changes, create a new branch. You can do this either by:

On GitHub, clicking the box on the top left that says â€œmasterâ€ and typing in whatever you want to call the new branch, or
Clicking â€œNew Branchâ€ in the Git pane in RStudio 

Preview your changes in one document by clicking â€œRenderâ€ in the editing pane. 
Preview your changes to the whole document by clicking â€œRender Bookâ€ in the Build pane. 
Commit your changes to your working branch.
If youâ€™d like to have your changes reviewed, push your commits to GitHub and notify the reviewer (likely Dave or Mike).
If your changes are ready for prime time, enter quarto publish into the Terminal. 
It will ask you to confirm if you want to update the website version of the Guide by typing â€œYesâ€/â€œyâ€/â€œYâ€.
